And many have done well as the stock market defied gravity yet again and pulled out of a short-lived correction on Sept. 10. The Nasdaq gained 5%, while the S&P 500 rose 3% last month. The…
Oil and gas explorer and producer Continental Resources (CLR) is once again at the forefront of technological innovation and advancement.

The Oklahoma City-based company isn't afraid to go after the higher-hanging fruit in the North Dakota Bakken Shale formation. As the Middle Bakken zone is starting to mature, Continental Resources is now leading the way in the lower Three Forks formation.

The firm is the sixth-biggest by market cap in IBD's Oil & Gas-U.S. Exploration and Production industry group, after EOG Resources (EOG), Anadarko Petroleum (APC), Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD), Devon Energy (DVN) and Noble Energy (NBL).

Continental, however, is the largest leaseholder in the Bakken area, operating 22 rigs across some 1.2 million net acres in the Williston Basin. The company is also the largest and the most active driller in the area, drilling about 300 net wells in 2013.
Cooking At Three Forks
As the largest producer, Continental derives about 65% of its total production from the Bakken play.

"If you think of the Williston Basin as a layer cake, you have the Middle Bakken — the main area that everyone was focused on at first," said Paul Grigel, analyst at Macquarie Research. Below that, there is an area called the Three Forks, which has four different benches. The first bench has proven to be very prospective across a large acreage swath for much of the industry, he says.

"The area where Continental is really leading the way is on the testing of the lower Three Forks benches," Grigel said. "There are some other industry peers who are testing various benches there, but Continental has the most thorough program to go through in both the second and third benches, and testing a couple of wells in the fourth bench."
Continental plans to drill 20 wells this year to test the commercial productivity of the three lowest benches. As of the end of the last quarter, it had finished 13 wells.

"We see oil there (in those deeper benches); we see the appropriate rock type that we think we can drill horizontal wells in and fracture stimulate. That program is about two-thirds of the way," said Continental President Rick Bott. "Results have been pretty much according to plan. We think we have proven now about a 3,800-square-mile area within the overall 15,000 to 18,000-square-mile area that's productive in the Middle Bakken.

"That is essentially helping the industry see that there is much more oil there to be gotten out at commercial rates than was previously thought. And that's not in a lot of estimates of the basin capacity."
Refining Some Techniques
Another initiative Continental has undertaken in the Bakken Shale formation is downspacing. In downspacing, the company drills more wells in the same acreage area, thus increasing production.
Continental applies what it calls an "appraisal approach": It tries to determine how far apart the wells need to be to try to maximize oil that can come out of the rock.

"After we get those results, we are going to do some more of these types of programs into 2014 and then probably if you look onward into 2015, we'll be taking all that knowledge and going into fulfilled development," said Bott.
Continental also has been using innovative techniques to cut costs and produce oil more efficiently.

By using what the company calls an ECO-pad, it is able to drill four wells from a single drilling pad in the same smaller area. After drilling the well, instead of having to disassemble and haul the rig to a new area, the ECO-pad walks from one hole to the next on hydraulic feet.
Not only is this technique more ecologically friendly with less impact on local farmers, but it also reduces costs, due to time savings and having less surface infrastructure.

"Think of it as buying in bulk," said Grigel. "They've done a good job in 2013 of reducing costs on the per-well cost front and that's something they want to continue to focus on in 2014." Grigel estimates the per-well cost savings to be 5% in 2014 from this technology.
Another promising area is the SCOOP, or the South Central Oklahoma Oil Province. Continental has 277,000 net acres prospective in the area.
Sideways In The SCOOP
The company is addressing the area with horizontal wells with the goal of unlocking value.
"They've shown some interesting results there. I think it's an area they're still working to understand as well as investors," said Grigel.
Continental is investing 15% of capital in the SCOOP this year and the company plans to allocate 25% of its budget in 2014.

In addition to the cost savings that come from using the ECO-pad, Continental also increased efficiencies in drilling and completion of wells and worked out transportation bottlenecks. It is currently using rail in addition to pipelines to transport oil.

The company also has shown strong capital discipline. Even though it has been outspending its cash flow due to continued capital expenditures, the rate of the outspending has slowed. Continental's credit was recently upgraded to investment grade by Standard & Poor's Rating Services.
Quarterly earnings grew at a strong double-digit rate in the past eight quarters, with significant acceleration in the past three. Revenue growth has slowed down in recent quarters.
In the second quarter, earnings per share were up 96% from a year ago to $1.33 as revenue rose 10% to $1.1 billion.
Pushing Ahead Production

The company has set its 2014 production target to between 26% and 32% growth, in line with analyst estimates. It plans to have 400 net well completions, a 22% year-over-year increase. Capital expenditures are expected to be $4.05 billion.
CEO Harold Hamm, who is Continental's founder, and his family hold a 74% controlling interest in the company's stock.

Risks for Continental include the level of oil prices as well as risks associated with exploration of unknown areas. Investors will be watching further developments in the downspacing and the Three Forks area, noted Grigel.

"It's an interesting story and they're certainly one of the leaders in the Williston Basin," added Grigel. "I think they're going to keep pressing forward with new concepts. It's an exciting time to be an investor or a company who is operating in the Williston Basin."

IBD's Oil & Gas-U.S. Exploration and Production industry group ranks No. 13 of 197 groups tracked.Oil and gas explorer and producer Continental Resources (CLR) is once again at the forefront of technological innovation and advancement.The Oklahoma City-based company isn't afraid to go after the higher-hanging fruit in the North Dakota Bakken Shale formation. As the Middle Bakken zone is starting to mature, Continental Resources is now leading the way in the lower Three Forks formation.The firm is the sixth-biggest by market cap in IBD's Oil & Gas-U.S. Exploration and Production industry group, after EOG Resources (EOG), Anadarko Petroleum (APC), Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD), Devon Energy (DVN) and Noble Energy (NBL).Continental, however, is the largest leaseholder in the Bakken area, operating 22 rigs across some 1.2 million net acres in the Williston Basin. The company is also the largest and the most active driller in the area, drilling about 300 net wells in 2013.Cooking At Three ForksAs the largest producer, Continental derives about 65% of its total production from the Bakken play."If you think of the Williston Basin as a layer cake, you have the Middle Bakken — the main area that everyone was focused on at first," said Paul Grigel, analyst at Macquarie Research. Below that, there is an area called the Three Forks, which has four different benches. The first bench has proven to be very prospective across a large acreage swath for much of the industry, he says."The area where Continental is really leading the way is on the testing of the lower Three Forks benches," Grigel said. "There are some other industry peers who are testing various benches there, but Continental has the most thorough program to go through in both the second and third benches, and testing a couple of wells in the fourth bench."Continental plans to drill 20 wells this year to test the commercial productivity of the three lowest benches. As of the end of the last quarter, it had finished 13 wells."We see oil there (in those deeper benches); we see the appropriate rock type that we think we can drill horizontal wells in and fracture stimulate. That program is about two-thirds of the way," said Continental President Rick Bott. "Results have been pretty much according to plan. We think we have proven now about a 3,800-square-mile area within the overall 15,000 to 18,000-square-mile area that's productive in the Middle Bakken."That is essentially helping the industry see that there is much more oil there to be gotten out at commercial rates than was previously thought. And that's not in a lot of estimates of the basin capacity."Refining Some TechniquesAnother initiative Continental has undertaken in the Bakken Shale formation is downspacing. In downspacing, the company drills more wells in the same acreage area, thus increasing production.Continental applies what it calls an "appraisal approach": It tries to determine how far apart the wells need to be to try to maximize oil that can come out of the rock."After we get those results, we are going to do some more of these types of programs into 2014 and then probably if you look onward into 2015, we'll be taking all that knowledge and going into fulfilled development," said Bott.Continental also has been using innovative techniques to cut costs and produce oil more efficiently.By using what the company calls an ECO-pad, it is able to drill four wells from a single drilling pad in the same smaller area. After drilling the well, instead of having to disassemble and haul the rig to a new area, the ECO-pad walks from one hole to the next on hydraulic feet.Not only is this technique more ecologically friendly with less impact on local farmers, but it also reduces costs, due to time savings and having less surface infrastructure."Think of it as buying in bulk," said Grigel. "They've done a good job in 2013 of reducing costs on the per-well cost front and that's something they want to continue to focus on in 2014." Grigel estimates the per-well cost savings to be 5% in 2014 from this technology.Another promising area is the SCOOP, or the South Central Oklahoma Oil Province. Continental has 277,000 net acres prospective in the area.Sideways In The SCOOPThe company is addressing the area with horizontal wells with the goal of unlocking value."They've shown some interesting results there. I think it's an area they're still working to understand as well as investors," said Grigel.Continental is investing 15% of capital in the SCOOP this year and the company plans to allocate 25% of its budget in 2014.In addition to the cost savings that come from using the ECO-pad, Continental also increased efficiencies in drilling and completion of wells and worked out transportation bottlenecks. It is currently using rail in addition to pipelines to transport oil.The company also has shown strong capital discipline. Even though it has been outspending its cash flow due to continued capital expenditures, the rate of the outspending has slowed. Continental's credit was recently upgraded to investment grade by Standard & Poor's Rating Services.Quarterly earnings grew at a strong double-digit rate in the past eight quarters, with significant acceleration in the past three. Revenue growth has slowed down in recent quarters.In the second quarter, earnings per share were up 96% from a year ago to $1.33 as revenue rose 10% to $1.1 billion.Pushing Ahead ProductionThe company has set its 2014 production target to between 26% and 32% growth, in line with analyst estimates. It plans to have 400 net well completions, a 22% year-over-year increase. Capital expenditures are expected to be $4.05 billion.CEO Harold Hamm, who is Continental's founder, and his family hold a 74% controlling interest in the company's stock.Risks for Continental include the level of oil prices as well as risks associated with exploration of unknown areas. Investors will be watching further developments in the downspacing and the Three Forks area, noted Grigel."It's an interesting story and they're certainly one of the leaders in the Williston Basin," added Grigel. "I think they're going to keep pressing forward with new concepts. It's an exciting time to be an investor or a company who is operating in the Williston Basin."IBD's Oil & Gas-U.S. Exploration and Production industry group ranks No. 13 of 197 groups tracked.

Fresh highs for the Nasdaq and S&P 500 in recent days have resulted in a plentiful crop of stocks hitting 52-week highs. Tuesday was no different as energy, technology and retail sectors were well represented.Perhaps nowhere have 52-week highs been more prominent than in IBD's Oil & Gas-U.S. Exploration & Production group. The group didn't disappoint Tuesday. Noble Energy (NBL), a member of this week's IBD Big Cap list of top-rated growth stocks, rose nearly 1%. The stock hasn't looked back after a flat-base breakout in September. Meanwhile, group peer Whiting Petroleum (WLL) added 1.5%. It's working on seven straight weekly price gains after a breakout over 53.67 in September.Elsewhere, Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) rose 2.5% in heavy volume ahead of earnings after the close. Late Tuesday, the restaurant chain reported earnings of 95 cents a share, up 65% from a year ago. Sales rose 28% to $315.8 million. Shares surged 11% in after-hours trading.Visa (V) rose fractionally ahead of Wednesday's earnings report after the close. It's now 4% above a recent buy point of 196.10. Visa's latest breakout in September was from a late-stage base. Late-stage base breakouts are riskier buys because the stock has made a big price run already.Visa continues to deliver impressive growth for a company with a market capitalization of $132 billion. Third-quarter earnings are expected to rise 20% to $1.85 a share. Sales are seen rising 11% to just over $3 billion.SS&C Technologies (SSNC) rose fractionally ahead of its earnings report Thursday after the close. Profit is seen rising 28% to 50 cents a share with sales up 9% to $181.5 million. The company provides software products for the financial services industry that help automate and integrate front- and back-office functions. It closed just underneath a flat-base buy point of 40.04.Flowers Foods (FLO) extended gains after a recent breakout from a cup-shaped base. Shares rose 1% in heavy volume. It's only 3% above its latest buy point of 24.60. The company's growth-through-acquisition strategy has resulted in strong sales growth in recent quarters. Over the past three quarters, sales growth has accelerated from 15% to 26% to 32%.Click here to view the full list of 52-Week New Highs & Lows.

Oil and gas driller Noble Energy (NBL) posted rising sales and adjusted earnings in the fourth quarter on high crude prices, and announced a 40% surge in 2012 production, as several anticipated projects come online.
Earnings climbed 13% at the Houston-based company to $1.18 per share, a penny above views. Revenue climbed 26% to $985 million, also above estimates.

The results back out one-time items, including a $620 million impairment charge on the write-down in value of several of its U.S. fields, connected to lower natural gas prices. But it realized an average crude price of $101.12 per barrel in the quarter, up 22% from a year ago.
Shares were little changed on above-average volume in intraday trading.

The company said past investments should yield results in 2012. It expects oil and gas output to climb 40% globally this year, due largely to projects on land in the U.S., within the Gulf of Mexico, and offshore in Equatorial Guinea. U.S. volumes are expected to climb 22% from 2011.
Noble forecast 2012 sales volume would rise to between 244,000 and 256,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, which would be a 13% hike at the midpoint from 2011.
"Noble Energy is now positioned to accelerate our growth in production and cash flow with contributions from each of our five core areas," CEO Charles Davidson said in a statement.
The company is also raising its capital products spending. It expects to spend $3.5 billion in 2012, up from about $3 billion in 2011. By 2016 it expects to be spending $5 billion a year.
A slew of other producers have posted higher than expected Q4 earnings on high oil prices, including giant Exxon Mobil (XOM), ConocoPhillips (COP) and Occidental Petroleum (OXY).

Chesapeake Energy (CHK) is due out later this month.Oil and gas driller Noble Energy (NBL) posted rising sales and adjusted earnings in the fourth quarter on high crude prices, and announced a 40% surge in 2012 production, as several anticipated projects come online.Earnings climbed 13% at the Houston-based company to $1.18 per share, a penny above views. Oil-and-gas exploration and biotech stocks continue to dominate the list of 20 leading big-cap stocks, but a few others are near buy points. Discovery Communications (DISCA), which operates TV channels such as Discovery, TLC and Animal Planet, is just below an 89.68 flat-base buy point. The pattern is third-stage, which tends to be riskier than those in earlier stages. Also,…
There are two keys to Frank Caruso's investment strategy.
First, the lead manager of $2 billion AllianceBernstein Large Cap Growth directs his team to seek what he calls dynamic gaps.
Those gaps are big differences between how fast Caruso's team expects a stock's earnings to grow and Wall Street's consensus expectation.
The second key is where Caruso has his team look for that gap: four to five years out.
Caruso is adamant about avoiding a focus on the near term.
This approach had the fund up 32.46% this year through Nov. 30. That topped 78% of its large-cap growth peers, which averaged 29.96%. The S&P 500 was up 29.12%.
Over the past three years the fund's average annual gain is 18.14% vs. 15.70% for its peer group and 17.73% for the big-cap bogey.
Caruso, age 57, discussed his investment process with IBD from his office in Manhattan.
IBD: How does your search for leading stocks differ from other growth investors'?

Caruso: We think of equities generally (in terms of) a combination of growth and capital returns in the form of dividends and share buybacks, which support the valuations of equities over a long period.

And we take a long-duration approach to investment opportunities. But most growth investors are dangerously focused on the moment, growth in the short term. We try to exploit this phenomenon where not a lot of analytical work is being done four to five years out.
IBD: Give me some examples that show how your tack works, please.

Caruso: In the spring of 2012, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) missed a couple of months of sales estimates and the stock was crushed. It went from about 440 to 230 a share. But our research let us be marginal buyers in that lurch. We were confident in the caliber of management. We bought a distressed stock in a great long-term franchise (between May and July 2012 between 380 and 400). Later, they began to execute and sales improved. (We added to our position) through the beginning of October 2012 at prices between 284 and 330.
IBD: Is Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) another example? You added a big chunk to your stake a few quarters ago.

Caruso: They have a great core competency in technologies that are increasingly desired by clients: in the cloud and in mobility. It's been growing in the high teens and low 20s for years. It has no debt, and it has excess cash.
After putting up a strong quarter, they got caught up in the immigration debate. They rely on a lot of foreign visas to conduct their business. The stock went down about 25% in a heartbeat.

That was an opportunity for us to reload. In the spring of 2012 we started initiating. The stock broke down into the high 50s (from 78). We met with Cognizant managers for three or four hours, and we left convinced they still had a great business and plan. The stock moved higher. The immigration debate percolated, and we bought in the 60s. Now it's in the 90s.
IBD: Are you looking for investment opportunities created by the prospect of the Federal Reserve tapering its bond buys?
Caruso: We don't try to overthink the macro environment. So our marching orders to our analysts are to focus on company fundamentals.

But when (Fed Chairman Ben) Bernanke started the tapering discussion, after having underperformed the broad market and value in particular the prior 12 to 15 months, growth securities started to do well. So the market response to tapering seems to have catalyzed a shift on the margin to growth stocks.
IBD: Is that because growth stocks tend to have more foreign exposure?

Caruso: Yes, growth stocks generally have a little more exposure to foreign earnings growth. And U.S. value stocks have more exposure to, let's say, earnings that are fueled by Federal Reserve stimulus steps. This is speculation on my part, but the discussion regarding tapering might auger well for future growth stock performance.
IBD: Computer services, software and systems are your largest category of holdings at 12.36% of assets. Why do you expect good things from them?

Caruso: Cognizant is one, with close to a 4% weighting. The portfolio is built around companies like that and Google (GOOG). We think of Priceline (PCLN) as a service company. Some people think of it as a technology company.
Ansys (ANSS) is an engineering simulation software company. People think of this as a company that benefits from innovation.

In the old days, you had a team of engineers design a new product, build mockups, then software would run calculations that tested stress characteristics. It was on the tail end of the innovation. And it might take weeks to run those simulations.
Today you can run millions of simulations before you even get to the real engineering side of things.
IBD: Biotech is your second-largest industry group, with 5.45% of assets. Why are you focused there?

Caruso: Biotech came out of a very long, severe stock price underperformance. Now we're seeing far greater pipeline productivity emerging from a couple of leaders. We've centered our investments on Celgene (CELG), Biogen (BIIB) and Gilead (GILD). Each is in a different area of disease management.

Biogen has been mostly a multiple sclerosis story. They've come to market with a new oral medicine called Tecfidera, which has experienced one of the most unbelievably successful product launches in pharmacology history. But (investors) have been so focused on MS that they haven't paid attention to some of the products that are in development.

There is a hemophilia product (Eloctate) that we expect to launch in mid-next year. It has the opportunity to take share from Baxter (BAX) and drive growth. And there's upside left for Tecfidera for a long time to come.

Gilead is basically an HIV and hepatitis C story. It has new product launches on the horizon. We expect Gilead to remain dominant in HIV in the near- to midterm. Their hepatitis C portfolio is starting to contribute meaningfully to corporate growth.
Celgene is a multiple myeloma story, a cancer story. We see expanding use of the marketplace.
All of these companies were coming off of pretty conservative valuations for the kind of growth we envision them experiencing for the next couple of years.
IBD: Why did you trim your Facebook (FB) stake recently? You could not have foreseen the pullback that began in mid-October.
Caruso: The stock had an amazing run after reporting Q2 earnings. They demonstrated great acceleration in their mobility business, which people got excited about. The stock doubled in a short time.
We made a meaningful reduction in exposure in that euphoria. It had become close to 3% of the portfolio. So we cut our position roughly in half. It is roughly 1.5% today.

Their 20% fall? The stock had gone up the day they reported earnings. Then management talked about the need to spend more on investing in people and their product. A lot of highly valued, high-growth companies have seen similar price corrections.
I'm comfortable owning the stock. At the right price, we're getting back in.
IBD: Michael Kors (KORS) is relatively new for you. Are you concerned that earnings-per-share growth has sharply decelerated in recent quarters?

Caruso: We're always concerned about decelerating growth rates. But Kors' decline is to a less-than-extraordinary level. That's still better than a lot of companies. The stock is reasonably valued for the kind of growth we envision. They have opportunities in Europe and elsewhere overseas. Kors is seen as differentiated here and overseas.
IBD: Any surprise to Starbucks' (SBUX) accelerating EPS growth?

Caruso: No. They're just an unbelievable company. They're one of the few that has been able to consistently reinvent themselves. They've done a brilliant job of expanding their product offerings in small footprint stores, in being first to market in using new technologies to connect to their customers and their rewards programs are best in their class.
IBD: Precision Castparts (PCP) is up this year, but you've done some trimming. What are your concerns?

Caruso: They are persistent in acquiring businesses that let them leverage their own infrastructure. And they're an important supplier to Boeing (BA) on the 787. They generate about $10 million of content on every 787 that Boeing ships. Part of our reduction is that we own both companies. If we sell, it probably will be out of Boeing. Precision has lagged Boeing, so Precision has more upside.
IBD: Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) is way down this year. Yet you've added to your position in some recent quarters. Are you still optimistic?

Caruso: This has been the most disappointing stock in the portfolio in 2013. The interest we had was centered on the uniqueness of their business. There are no competitors at their scale. Robotic surgery is here to stay and will continue to grow.
Procedure growth continues to expand at a midteen clip year over year. The issue with execution relates to installation sales, which has slowed, especially in the U.S.

We expect a couple more tough quarters. Procedure growth will continue in the 16% area. There's no competition. Unbelievably high margins, big share buyback, no debt. Hopefully, it will be a contrary growth stock that recovers.
IBD: Are you concerned that LinkedIn's (LNKD) EPS growth has slowed for two quarters?

Caruso: They've brought a new (advertising product for mobile devices) to market. It will help their growth rate re-accelerate into next year. Like we did with Facebook, we made decent sales in the summer on the market euphoria around this stock. We're more interested in finding a price to re-engage LinkedIn than Facebook.

We think of it as a core holding, a business that's tough to replicate due to their network effect and LinkedIn managers who think of this as a business and want it to be profitable. It's a good business that is richly valued. It will grow into that. So getting the entry and trim points right is important.

IBD: Noble Energy's (NBL) EPS growth has soared the past two quarters. But tumbling crude oil prices have doused energy producer stocks' spark lately. This stock has pulled back about 10% since Oct. 30. Why stick with it?

Caruso: Noble is one of the best-positioned energy companies by way of its fracking inventory. Overseas — in Israel and Africa — they have unbelievable reserves. And they are really good operators, really focused on creating value.
Energy firms are more volatile than what we typically engage, but this company's assets are special.

We've seen a reduction in underlying commodity prices, so we would welcome an opportunity to buy some of this back, make it larger in the portfolio. It's not quite at a point where we would start buying it back.
IBD: What's the biggest change you've made since taking this fund's helm in February 2012?

Caruso: Basically, our perception of growth is linked to a company's ability to create long-term value. So our focus is further forward than many other investors' focus is. It's more on the economics of business and profitability than on the hunt for earnings growth, which is sometimes very episodic. We're still looking for opportunities in large-cap growth. But we're focused on the longer term.
IBD: What was the fund's prior time horizon?

Caruso: I can't say, but it was probably more consistent with most growth managers'. Annual turnover in growth portfolios is often 100% to 150%. We're trying to do closer to 50%. We want great franchises that have the ability to win over a very long time. I tell my analysts I want them to understand how companies are competitively differentiated. I don't want them spending their time trying to anticipate when a bad business is a good stock.There are two keys to Frank Caruso's investment strategy.First, the lead manager of $2 billion AllianceBernstein Large Cap Growth directs his team to seek what he calls dynamic gaps.Those gaps are big differences between how fast Caruso's team expects a stock's earnings to grow and Wall Street's consensus expectation.The second key is where Caruso has his team look for that gap: four to five years out.Caruso is adamant about avoiding a focus on the near term.This approach had the fund up 32.46% this year through Nov. 30. But tumbling crude oil prices have doused energy producer stocks' spark lately. This stock has pulled back about 10% since Oct. 30. Why stick with it?Caruso: Noble is one of the best-positioned energy companies by way of its fracking inventory. Overseas — in Israel and Africa — they have unbelievable reserves. And they are really good operators, really focused on creating value.Energy firms are more volatile than what we typically engage, but this company's assets are special.We've seen a reduction in underlying commodity prices, so we would welcome an opportunity to buy some of this back, make it larger in the portfolio. It's not quite at a point where we would start buying it back.IBD: What's the biggest change you've made since taking this fund's helm in February 2012?Caruso: Basically, our perception of growth is linked to a company's ability to create long-term value. So our focus is further forward than many other investors' focus is. It's more on the economics of business and profitability than on the hunt for earnings growth, which is sometimes very episodic. We're still looking for opportunities in large-cap growth. But we're focused on the longer term.IBD: What was the fund's prior time horizon?Caruso: I can't say, but it was probably more consistent with most growth managers'. Annual turnover in growth portfolios is often 100% to 150%. We're trying to do closer to 50%. We want great franchises that have the ability to win over a very long time. I tell my analysts I want them to understand how companies are competitively differentiated. I don't want them spending their time trying to anticipate when a bad business is a good stock.
When you think of Texas-based oil companies, you probably don't think of deepwater rigs in faraway places like Malta, Equatorial Guinea, Australia or Thailand.

Then again, Atwood Oceanics (ATW) isn't your typical Texas oil company. For one thing, it doesn't drill on land. For another, only a tiny portion of its revenue, about 5%, comes from the U.S. Most of its business is centered in the South Pacific or off the coast of West Africa.

Atwood specializes in the drilling and completion of exploratory and developmental oil and gas wells. Its fleet of 13 rigs includes semisubmersibles, deepwater drillships and jack-up rigs. It also has three ultra-deepwater drillships under construction.

The company maintains offices on five continents and boasts a multinational workforce of 1,200 people. It makes money by charging day rates to oil companies for using its rigs. Its biggest clients include Chevron (CVX), Noble Energy (NBL) and Kosmos Energy (KOS).
Heavy demand for oil in many global markets has pushed day rates to a range of $550,000 to $600,000 a day, well above the historical norm.
Competitive Advantage

These high rates have led to an expansion of the number of fleets on the water. Although this means more competition for Atwood, the company has a number of advantages over most other drillers, analysts say.
"Among offshore drillers, Atwood is one of the companies that is better positioned to take advantage of current conditions," said Ian Macpherson, an analyst at Simmons & Co. International.

"They have relatively modern assets, so they are not as exposed to the threat of obsolescence as other companies," he said. "And they're small enough that the investments they make have a material effect on earnings."
Those investments include efforts to expand Atwood's fleet of deepwater drillships, which can drill in water 12,000 feet deep.

It takes $650 million to build a drillship, and five or six years to pay one off at current day rates. That's a hefty sum for Atwood, which had $787 million in revenue last year. But the company has shown a knack for turning investments into profits.

"They have a pretty good balance of capitalizing and free cash flow," Macpherson said. "Historically, they also have better-than-average return on capital and they're pretty reliable in terms of operating efficiency. Some of the smaller competitors are a little more extended now and less able to expand their assets."
Of the three deepwater drillships currently under construction, two are already under contract.

The latest of those deals was announced June 10, when Atwood was awarded a drilling services contract for the Atwood Achiever drillship by a subsidiary of Kosmos Energy. The contract is for an exploration program off the coast of Morocco.
The Achiever is one of the rigs under construction at the Daewoo Shipbuilding and Marine Engineering shipyard in South Korea. It is scheduled for delivery in June 2014.

The new contract specifies a base operating rate of $595,000 per day over three years. It adds $652 million in revenue backlog, bringing Atwood's total revenue backlog to around $3.9 billion as of June 10.

Haithum Nokta, an analyst at Clarkson Capital Markets, notes that the Achiever might eventually move to other operating locations "for which the day rate will be properly adjusted" for differences in taxes and operating costs.
"We believe other potential locations may be Mauritania and Suriname," Nokta added. "We view the contract positively, and the rate comes in line with recent fixtures in the region."
Two more new contracts, both for existing rigs, were also announced this month.

One of them involves the Atwood Beacon, a jack-up rig that is currently operating off the coast of Israel under an agreement with Italian energy company Eni S.p.A. When that work ends, probably in July, the Beacon will move off the coast of Italy under a new two-year contract that will add $128 million in revenue backlog.

The other contract, with Shell Offshore, involves the Atwood Condor semisubmersible rig. Work under the new contract will probably begin in late August. The contract is for 39 months and involves a day rate of about $550,000 for a drilling program in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico. It adds about $502 million in revenue backlog.
Financially, Atwood has produced pretty steady growth over the past few years, with only the occasional hiccup.
Sales And Earnings

The company has run off three straight quarters of double-digit sales and earnings growth. During its fiscal second quarter, which ended in March, it logged earnings of $1.28 a share. That was up 42% from the prior year and a nickel above consensus analyst estimates.
Revenue for the quarter gained 48% to $253.2 million, the highest increase in more than four years, but slightly below views.
The company's stock price touched a nearly five-year high of 56.71 June 18 and currently trades near 55.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect fiscal Q3 earnings of $1.34 a share, which would be a 70% year-over-year gain. Profit for the full year is seen rising 25% to $5.16 a share.

"(Atwood) has the mix of backlog and newbuild catalysts that we find attractive, and we believe more announcements of ultra-deepwater contracts will result in further rig additions and continued multiyear earnings growth," noted Matt Beeby, an analyst at Williams Financial Group.
The movement of day rates will play a part in future earnings. Analyst Macpherson says current day rates "are pretty mature," and are not likely to go much higher.
"But I also don't think they are vulnerable to collapse either," he added.
What has gone up are costs to operate the rigs, mainly because heightened competition for labor has narrowed the number of skilled crew members.

"The top end of the labor spectrum is very competitive right now, so those costs have been rising," Macpherson said. "Insurance costs are also rising. You tend to see higher costs on everything in these kinds of expansionary cycles."When you think of Texas-based oil companies, you probably don't think of deepwater rigs in faraway places like Malta, Equatorial Guinea, Australia or Thailand.Then again, Atwood Oceanics (ATW) isn't your typical Texas oil company. Before George Mikan was a legend, he was a boy who looked up to his father for guidance.

Joe Mikan, who helped operate Mikan's Tavern in Illinois, was as workmanlike as his blue-collar clientele, wrote Michael Schumacher in "Mr. Basketball: George Mikan, the Minneapolis Lakers and the Birth of the NBA."
"Do the best you can," Joe Mikan told George, "and so be judged."

With that advice, a healthy dose of determination and the guidance of his DePaul University basketball coach, Ray Meyer, Mikan transformed from a clumsy, 6-10 project who with his thick glasses and dark hair looked like Clark Kent, into basketball's Superman.
Mikan (1924-2005) simply was pro basketball's first great big man.

A prolific scorer and rebounder, Mikan led his pro teams to seven titles, one with the Chicago American Gears of the National Basketball League and six with the Minneapolis Lakers, who ended up in the National Basketball Association.
Towering

He was so impressive, the Associated Press in 1950 named him Mr. Basketball for the first half of the 20th century. "I felt determined to live up to the honor," Mikan wrote in his autobiography, "Unstoppable: The Story of George Mikan." "I never had to look any further than that award for inspiration."

Three of his five Laker titles were still to come. Mikan's 1950-51 season was best statistically. He led the league in scoring at 28.4 points per game, his highest, and finished second in rebounding at 14.1.

With career averages of 23.1 points and 13.4 rebounds per game, Mikan led his teams to seven professional basketball titles overall. Elected to Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in 1959, he was named one of 50 Greatest Players in NBA History in 1996.
"Mikan was a competitor; he never gave up during a game," said John Kundla, 96, who coached him in Minneapolis. "He was easy to coach, to get along with."

Whitey Skoog, a Mikan teammate, said: "George was an intelligent man. He was a good teammate and didn't make a lot of mistakes. He had a lot of pride in his performance. George practiced that way and played that way."
Mikan's dominance changed the game, prompting rules changes that included goaltending, widening the free-throw lane, and the 24-second clock.
A life-size statue of Mikan stands at Minneapolis' Target Center, home to the NBA's Timberwolves.

"He showed the world a big man could be an athlete," Wilt Chamberlain, who followed as a titanic big man in the 1960s, told USA Today three years before his death in 1999. "Not just some big guy who could hardly walk and chew gum at the same time. He was a splendid athlete. He was the first true superstar of the league."

Mikan squeezed the NBA onto the national stage alongside baseball, the era's giant. "He literally transcended the sport and he created such visibility," said Bob Cousy, who in the 1950s helped start the Boston Celtics' dynasty. "He lifted us out of the doldrums and made the league respectable."
Standard-Bearer
Mikan was an ambassador for pro basketball, which as with football in the 1940s and '50s was considered by many minor against the college game.

Mikan, who would earn a law degree and become commissioner of the American Basketball Association, showed his business and marketing acumen. He didn't miss opportunities, either orchestrated by the NBA or on his own, to mingle with the fans. And he cultivated a good relationship with the press.

When Mikan died at age 80, champion center Shaquille O'Neal recalled of his predecessor: "I know who he was. I know what he did. Without George Mikan, there is no me." O'Neal went on to offer to pay for Mikan's funeral, and did.
Born in Joliet, Ill., Mikan grew up working in the family tavern business. Later he tended bar.

After failing to make his freshman basketball team, he transferred to another school. "Mikan would never accept defeat, even the suggestion that there was something he couldn't do, once he applied himself," Schumacher said.
Big Man On Campus
He was so effective his senior year, DePaul University offered him a basketball scholarship. Soon the Chicago school had a new coach, Ray Meyer, who grasped that "this big guy is my future."
Mikan not only brought height, but also bulk in his shoulders.
Meyer made Mikan his main project, putting his willing pupil through a battery of drills to boost his skills and athleticism.
The right-handed Mikan learned to use his left hand by launching 300 shots a day.
To help Mikan get off the ground better on his hook shots, Meyer put a bench near the basket that the kid had to jump over while firing.

That hook lived on decades later. "He showed us how to do it," said Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who rode the sky hook to the Hall of Fame. "I certainly would not have the hook shot that went in if it wasn't for the fundamentals I learned from George Mikan's game."
Said Schumacher: "Meyer worked with Mikan all the time and after hours. He saw something in Mikan, his absolute drive to succeed. And not just succeed, but excel."

Mikan proved a quick study. He became a three-time All-American and was named College Player of the Year twice. Mikan led DePaul to the National Invitation Tournament title in 1945, when the NIT was a major event. His 53 points beat Rhode Island in the semifinals and helped him win the NIT's Most Valuable Player award.
After college, Mikan signed with Chicago's NBL team. He promptly took the Gears to the 1947 league title while averaging 16.5 points per game.
When the team folded the next year, Mikan wound up with Minneapolis' Lakers and took them to the 1948 NBL championship.
The Lakers jumped to a new league, the Basketball Association of America, the next season, and Mikan led the team to a familiar result — another title — by averaging 30 points in 10 playoff games.
The NBA was born when the BAA and the NBL merged in the fall of 1949. Mikan led it in scoring at 27.4 points per game and won a fourth straight pro championship.
That run ended the next year, largely due to Mikan's fractured leg in the playoffs.
"Mikan went home and dreamed about starting a new string of titles," Schumacher wrote. "He'd never forget the one that got away."
Said Skoog: "When George walked on the court, the intention was to win that game. He was a highly competitive man."
Mikan cemented his legacy by leading the Lakers to three more titles. He was out of the game by age 32, four years before the team moved to Los Angeles in 1960.
Good Guy

Mikan was known as a gentle giant off the court. It was a demeanor applauded by Terry Mikan, one of six children from George and Patricia, who said after his father's death that "whenever he would make a toast at a family function, Dad would ask us to raise our glass to kindness."

On the court, Mikan was hardly gentle. He was simply driven to perfection. "Mikan had a work ethic," Schumacher said. "He wanted to be the best. That was George Mikan. It wasn't enough to be on a good team. He had to be on the best team. It wasn't good enough to be a good NBA center. He had to be the best NBA center."Before George Mikan was a legend, he was a boy who looked up to his father for guidance.Joe Mikan, who helped operate Mikan's Tavern in Illinois, was as workmanlike as his blue-collar clientele, wrote Michael Schumacher in "Mr. Basketball: George Mikan, the Minneapolis Lakers and the Birth of the NBA.""Do the best you can," Joe Mikan told George, "and so be judged."With that advice, a healthy dose of determination and the guidance of his DePaul University basketball coach, Ray Meyer, Mikan transformed from a clumsy, 6-10 project who with his thick glasses and dark hair looked like Clark Kent, into basketball's Superman.Mikan (1924-2005) simply was pro basketball's first great big man.A prolific scorer and rebounder, Mikan led his pro teams to seven titles, one with the Chicago American Gears of the National Basketball League and six with the Minneapolis Lakers, who ended up in the National Basketball Association.ToweringHe was so impressive, the Associated Press in 1950 named him Mr. Basketball for the first half of the 20th century. A stock's daily and weekly charts are two of your most valuable tools when it comes to investing.
Why? The price and volume action of a stock can help you spot bases and potential buy points, institutional buying and selling, and general bullish or bearish movement.
Charts also can reveal a stock's fatal flaw.
A sound basing pattern often shows tight price action and certain volume trends.
Stocks showing bullish behavior tend to close near their session highs, often in heavier trade. That signals support by institutional investors.
But a stock closing in the bottom half of its daily or weekly range displays a lack of support. Since the big money accounts for most of a stock's move, it's best to have them on your side.
Noble Energy (NBL) advanced to an all-time high the week ended April 23 1. But it reversed lower to close down 4%, near the bottom of its weekly range, to kick off the left side of a basing pattern.

The next week, the Houston-based oil and gas explorer finished in the lower third of the week's action 2. In the five weeks that followed, the stock closed in the top half of its weekly range only once.
The last week of its flat base, the week ended July 4, the stock sliced its 10-week moving average as it closed near the week's low 3.
Two weeks later, Noble pierced its 40-week line in heavy trade 4. It fell further the next three weeks, also in big volume 5.

The stock has been trying to claw back up the past two weeks, but in thin volume. Noble still sits well below both key moving averages.A stock's daily and weekly charts are two of your most valuable tools when it comes to investing.Why? It fell further the next three weeks, also in big volume 5.The stock has been trying to claw back up the past two weeks, but in thin volume. Noble still sits well below both key moving averages.

5:15 p.m. Update: Stocks took a beating Monday after the World Bank called for a larger contraction in the global economy this year. Major indexes opened sharply lower, worsened throughout the session and closed at the day's lows.
The NYSE composite swooned 3.5%, sliced its 50-day moving average and nearly touched its 200-day line. The S&P 500 dumped 3.1%, breaching both its 200-day and 50-day lines.
Meanwhile, the Dow dropped 2.4% and undercut its 50-day moving average. And the Nasdaq, which held above its moving averages, shed 3.4%.
Volume dropped off sharply across the board from Friday's beefed-up levels  softening the hit.
Materials and energy stocks were among the heaviest hit. Russian steelmaker Mechel (MTL) gapped down and tumbled 17% in heavy trading.
Group mate AK Steel Holding (AKS) lost 13%.
Oil settled down $2.62 to $66.93 a barrel for July.
PetroQuest Energy (PQ) and Berry Petroleum (BRY) both tumbled 12% and sliced their respective 50-day lines.
Driller Atwood Oceanics (ATW) gapped down and shed 10%. It also breached its 50-day moving average.
On the upside, Ameristar Casinos (ASCA) gapped up and gained 3% on an upgrade.

Data on May existing-home sales will be out Tuesday, along with earnings from the likes of AeroVironment (AVAV), Kroger (KR) and Oracle (ORCL). The Federal Reserve also begins its two-day meeting Tuesday.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Close At New Lows
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The market closed at session lows Monday as selling picked up in the final minutes of an already weak day.
The NYSE composite plunged 3.5%, the Nasdaq 3.4%, the S&P 500 2.8% and the Dow 2.4%, according to preliminary figures.
Volume was sharply lower from Friday's options-related activity. That was a bit of a relief in an otherwise bad day.
Also, leading stocks that fell did so in light volume for the most part.
Metals and energy sectors were weakest.
3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Near Lows In Late Trade

5:15 p.m. Update: Stocks took a beating Monday after the World Bank called for a larger contraction in the global economy this year. Major indexes opened sharply lower, worsened throughout the session and closed at the day's lows.The NYSE composite swooned 3.5%, sliced its 50-day moving average and nearly touched its 200-day line. The S&P 500 dumped 3.1%, breaching both its 200-day and 50-day lines.Meanwhile, the Dow dropped 2.4% and undercut its 50-day moving average. And the Nasdaq, which held above its moving averages, shed 3.4%.Volume dropped off sharply across the board from Friday's beefed-up levels  softening the hit.Materials and energy stocks were among the heaviest hit. Russian steelmaker Mechel (MTL) gapped down and tumbled 17% in heavy trading.Group mate AK Steel Holding (AKS) lost 13%.Oil settled down $2.62 to $66.93 a barrel for July.PetroQuest Energy (PQ) and Berry Petroleum (BRY) both tumbled 12% and sliced their respective 50-day lines.Driller Atwood Oceanics (ATW) gapped down and shed 10%. It also breached its 50-day moving average.On the upside, Ameristar Casinos (ASCA) gapped up and gained 3% on an upgrade.Data on May existing-home sales will be out Tuesday, along with earnings from the likes of AeroVironment (AVAV), Kroger (KR) and Oracle (ORCL). The Federal Reserve also begins its two-day meeting Tuesday.4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Close At New LowsBY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIAThe market closed at session lows Monday as selling picked up in the final minutes of an already weak day.The NYSE composite plunged 3.5%, the Nasdaq 3.4%, the S&P 500 2.8% and the Dow 2.4%, according to preliminary figures.Volume was sharply lower from Friday's options-related activity. That was a bit of a relief in an otherwise bad day.Also, leading stocks that fell did so in light volume for the most part.Metals and energy sectors were weakest.3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Near Lows In Late Trade
Stocks edged higher in lower volume Monday as Wall Street readied for Twitter's IPO later in the week.

Earlier today, the online social network said it plans to raise $1.75 billion by offering 70 million shares at a price range of $23 to $25, up from a prior range of $17 to $20. The company will trade under the ticker TWTR.
At the close, the Nasdaq and S&P 500 each rose 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.2%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in lower than Friday's levels.

Major averages continue to trade tightly and hold near highs. Distribution days remain well-contained in the major averages. A small number of leaders look a bit worse for the wear, but many others are holding gains bullishly. The bottom line is that major averages and leading stocks aren't flashing meaningful sell signals yet.

IBD's Oil & Gas — U.S. Exploration & Production group was one of the day's top performers, rising about 3%. Leadership was widespread in the group. Continental Resources (CLR), EOG Resources (EOG) and Noble Energy (NBL), members of last week's IBD Big Cap 20 list of leading large-cap growth stocks, all outperformed Monday.

After the close, Houston-based oil and gas producer Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) earned 72 cents share, 2 cents above the consensus estimate. Sales were a tad light at just over $145 million, up 37% from a year ago. Shares fell 1% in early after-hours trading.
Group peer and market leader Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) was also scheduled to report but hadn't reported at publishing time.

In the stock market today, oil and gas producer Berry Petroleum (BRY) gapped out of a long consolidation. Shares jumped 6% in heavy volume after Linn Energy (LINE) raised its stock-for-stock offer for Berry by $600 million. The deal was first announced in February. Linn's revised offer now values the deal at $4.9 billion, including debt.
Elsewhere, China-based wealth manager Noah Holdings (NOAH) extended gains after recently finding support at its 50-day moving average. Shares rallied 6%. Earnings are due Nov. 18 after the close.

On the downside, BlackBerry (BBRY) slumped 16% after Fairfax Financial, the company's largest shareholder, walked away from a deal to buy the company. BlackBerry also said CEO Thorsten Heins is stepping down.
Tomorrow before the open, watch for earnings from AOL (AOL), Michael Kors (KORS) and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN).

Facebook (FB), Actavis (ACT), LinkedIn (LNKD) are atop a list of big cap companies with soaring sales growth amid a Q3 earnings season that has pointed to weak demand elsewhere, as seen in the 3.3% revenue growth among S&P 500 companies. Today's Screen Of The Day is Big Cap Leaders, companies with a market capitalization of at least $10 billion.…
5:15 p.m. Update: A soft-volume, mixed finish left the major indexes sagging deeply midway through the short week.
At Wednesday's close, the NYSE composite slumped 5.3% vs. last Friday's close. The S&P 500 was down 4.5%, the Nasdaq 4.2%, the Dow 3.2%.

Homebuilders were beaten up badly Wednesday after the Commerce Department reported that January housing starts and building permits had sunk to record lows. Fertilizer makers, insurers and Internet content providers logged some of the day's best gains.

After the close, Internet travel site Priceline (PCLN) jumped 13% upon reporting earnings of $1.29 a share vs. a consensus estimate of $1.05. Revenue swelled to $406 million, above expectations. The company upped its Q1 guidance to 85-95 cents a share vs. analysts' views for 58 cents.

The way John Freeman figures it, the world's oil supply was tight even before political turmoil erupted in the Middle East and North Africa. The price of crude had been climbing since late August as the global supply-demand equation shifted steadily toward the demand side. "The balance was such that you really couldn't afford to have any major supply sources…

A tale of two oil markets has emerged as turmoil in the Middle East and North Africa swells. It doesn't appear likely to end anytime soon, so oil companies' profits could depend on where their customers live. The difference between domestically traded West Texas Intermediate (WTI) and internationally traded Brent crude has widened to a record of $18 a barrel…

Oil and gas stocks lifted Tuesday amid upbeat company reports and forecasts of higher oil and gas prices ahead. That's tied to lower overall production, but Monday's Chevron (CVX) refinery fire could also contribute.

Many stocks in the Oil & Gas-U.S. Exploration & Production industry group rose, as Chesapeake Energy (CHK) jumped 9.4% on its quarterly report. The largest names all gained: Occidental Petroleum (OXY) 2.8%, Anadarko Petroleum (APC) 3.4%, EOG Resources (EOG) and Devon Energy Corp. (DVN) 2.8%, Noble Energy (NBL) 1.9% and Continental Resources (CLR) 3.7%.

Tuesday the U.S. Energy Information Administration projected that the Brent crude oil spot price will jump to about $103 per barrel in the second half of the year, from around $94 today. That's $3.50 higher than the EIA projected just last month.

"Overall, the market has been good. Oil prices have bounced off low levels. The spot price is now almost $94. As a result, names with strong secular growth in deep water exploration are doing well," Sterne Agee analyst Stephen Gangaro told IBD.
In the Oil & Gas-Machinery and Equipment group, National Oilwell Varco (NOV) closed up 1.6%, Baker Hughes (BHI) 2.2%, FMC Technologies (FMC) 1.1% and Weatherford International (WFT) 3.5%.

With "U.S. oil rig count having come down significantly in the last six to nine months, production starts to come down and investors feel better about the stability of the equipment industry," Gangaro said.
On Monday a massive fire struck Chevron's Richmond, Calif., refinery. The plant processes 245,000 barrels per day, about one-eighth of California's refining capacity.
The fire was out Tuesday, but Gangaro says its effect will depend on how long the refinery is down.
"You're in the summer driving season and it certainly could have an impact," he told IBD.

Elsewhere in the oil and gas machinery group, shares of smaller equipment maker Dril-Quip (DRQ) fell 2.8% even though the company late Monday reported Q2 results that topped analyst expectations, and lifted its guidance.
Dril-Quip's EPS jumped 35% to 74 cents, beating the Street's outlook by 4 cents. Sales soared 29% to $176.6 million. Analysts expected $169 million.
Gengaro says Dril-Quip is positioned well but "there is a little profit-taking" after shares rose before its quarterly report, in anticipation of strong results. Shares had risen 25% since May 26.

Oil and gas producer Chesapeake Energy reported that second-quarter revenue rose 2.1% to $3.389 billion. That trounced analysts' outlook for $2.442 billion.Oil and gas stocks lifted Tuesday amid upbeat company reports and forecasts of higher oil and gas prices ahead. There's a reason they call it the bottom line.
Every penny a company earns that survives the butcher's knife of materials costs, wages, taxes and capital spending deserves a place on the mantle.
An increasing horde of such pennies over several quarters often signals a company with sharp management, new products, improving market conditions or all of the above.
IBD analysis shows that a common characteristic of past market winners is an increase in the rate of earnings growth in the quarters preceding a stock's breakout.
For example, earnings gains may be 25% one quarter, then 30% the next period and 40% the next.
Such an improvement in earnings growth can also reveal a financial turnaround, the efficiencies from a recent merger, or new and more-efficient manufacturing operations beginning to gain traction.
Case in point: Patina Oil & Gas in late 1999.
The company had just come through five quarters of losses when earnings turned up in the second quarter of 1999 1. Growth accelerated to quadruple digits over the next four quarters 2.
Patina shaped its first base 3. It broke out from that pattern, then pulled back to its 10-week moving average 4, surging to new highs.
By the time the stock broke out of the base, the accelerating trend had been established. The acceleration continued as the stock made its pullback.
Earnings grew in steady triple digits through the first half of 2001.
Patina went on to gain 190% through May 2002.
Shares continued adding to those gains through a series of stock splits, until Patina was acquired by Noble Energy (NBL) in 2005.
To check companies' earnings growth in recent quarters, check the Company Earnings Reports table each day in IBD. The companies with accelerating growth bear a up-pointing arrow.
The mini-charts in the IBD 100, Your Weekly Review and other features include the EPS performance of the two most recent periods.
Daily Graphs Online, a sister product of IBD, includes earnings results for the eight latest quarters, plus the company's five-year EPS growth rate.

Remember to research the company's sales, margins and other key characteristics before buying shares. Also, make sure the general market is in a confirmed rally.There's a reason they call it the bottom line.Every penny a company earns that survives the butcher's knife of materials costs, wages, taxes and capital spending deserves a place on the mantle.An increasing horde of such pennies over several quarters often signals a company with sharp management, new products, improving market conditions or all of the above.IBD analysis shows that a common characteristic of past market winners is an increase in the rate of earnings growth in the quarters preceding a stock's breakout.For example, earnings gains may be 25% one quarter, then 30% the next period and 40% the next.Such an improvement in earnings growth can also reveal a financial turnaround, the efficiencies from a recent merger, or new and more-efficient manufacturing operations beginning to gain traction.Case in point: Patina Oil & Gas in late 1999.The company had just come through five quarters of losses when earnings turned up in the second quarter of 1999 1. The deep-water drilling permit freeze has kept companies and workers in limbo for the past 10 months. But pressure is building on the Obama administration to OK new activity in the Gulf of Mexico and other offshore sites. The U.S. government froze new deep-water drilling after last April's BP (BP) Macondo oil well disaster, though the official ban ended in October.…

Stocks ramped up again Thursday on falling oil prices and better-than-expected earnings reports, but bad news from some bellwethers after the close put a damper on the day's proceedings. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 both rose 1.2% during regular trading hours. The NYSE composite climbed 1%. The Dow industrials led the charge, ramping up 1.8% thanks to bullish earnings reports…
5:15 p.m. Update: Despite a round of better-than-expected economic data, stocks fell Friday and closed the week with losses.

The NYSE composite shed 1.2% Friday and S&P 500 1.1%. Both were dragged lower by energy and financials issues. Insurance stocks also hurt both indexes. They sold off despite the government's granting of $22 billion in bailout funds for insurers.
Meanwhile, the Dow fell 0.8% and Nasdaq lost 0.5%.
Volume dipped on both exchanges, allowing the indexes to dodge a distribution day.
For the week, the NYSE composite fell 5.6%, the S&P 500 5% and the Dow 3.6%. The Nasdaq snapped its nine-week win streak, falling 3.4%.
Leaders were mostly quiet Friday. Only a few rose or fell on above-average volume.
Red Hat (RHT) surged nearly 10% on more than doubled its average trade. The software maker cleared 19.26 from a flat base.
Aeropostale (ARO) dropped over 5% in heavy trading. It ended a seven-week advance. The apparel maker reports earnings May 21. Analysts see profit surging 85% to 48 cents a share.
Computer Programs & Systems (CPSI) reversed early gains and fell 4% on brisk trade. The health care IT firm finished just above its 50-day moving average.
On the upside, Air Methods (AIRM) jumped 8% on double its average volume. The provider of emergency medical services may be forming a cup-with-handle within a larger consolidation.
Elsewhere, no economic reports are due Monday. Home improvement retailer Lowe's (LOW) is among the few companies reporting earnings.
4:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Fall On Light Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks gave up morning gains and finished lower Friday. But a late-session rally trimmed some losses.
The NYSE composite dropped 1.2%, the S&P 500 1.1%, the Dow 0.8% and the Nasdaq 0.5%.
According to preliminary data, volume fell across the board. Decliners beat advancers nearly 2-to-1 on the NYSE and about 3-to-2 on the Nasdaq.
Insurance, financials and energy were among the day's worst performers. Appliance and software makers bucked the weakness.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Extend Losses In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks stumbled to new session lows in late trading Friday and were on pace to close the week with losses.
The NYSE composite dropped 1.6%, hurt mostly by financial and energy stocks. The S&P 500 fell 1.4%, the Dow 1.1% and the Nasdaq 0.6%.
Volume was tracking a bit higher on the NYSE and about even on the Nasdaq. Decliners beat advancers 2-to-1 on the NYSE and by slightly less than 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Red Hat (RHT) rallied 7% and cleared a 19.25 buy point from a flat base. Jefferies & Co. raised its price target to 21 and said that IBM (IBM) may be interested in buying the software maker.
